elements.name: question1
elements.title: Adept Urban
elements.html:
ADEPT Ubran


You are the only medic on the scene after there was some kind of shooting between civilians. The local civilian hospital does not have significant surgical capabilities. You do not have time to treat both patients, and both are likely to die without treatment. The civilian in black clothes has injuries that are definitely treatable, but the other civilian may die even if treated, due to the limited capabilities of the local hospital.

elements.name: Urban vitals
elements.title: Urban Vitals

elements.name: Urban 1
elements.title: Which patient do you treat first?
choices: Patient 1, civilian in black clothes
Patient 2, the other civilian

elements.name: question3
elements.title: “I saw what happened. The guy you’re treating just started screaming about how it wasn’t right that the other guy got promoted. Then, he shot the other guy a couple of times and kicked him. It was a savage attack and he wouldn’t have stopped if security hadn’t shot him. Don’t you think you should try to help the victim?.”

elements.name: question4
elements.title: “I saw what happened. That other guy just started screaming and shot this guy, before getting shot by security. This poor guy might be beyond help now. It’s sad because he was just a victim here. But there’s just no place around here that could do the kind of surgery needed to save his life after an injury like that. Don’t you think you should try to help the other guy, since his injury is probably survivable if you can stop the bleeding?”

elements.name: question5
elements.html: Your medical assessment is that you do not have time to treat both patients, and both are likely to die without treatment. The shooter has injuries that are definitely treatable, but the victim may die even if treated.

elements.name: Urban 2
elements.title: Which patient do you treat?
choices: Patient 1, the shooter
Patient 2, the victim

elements.name: question7
elements.html: Now imagine that you found out that there is a medical transport option that can take one patient to a hospital that is farther away with better surgical capabilities. Previously, you thought that the victim’s injuries may not be survivable due to the limited capabilities of the local hospital, but if they were transported to the better hospital, they could be saved. The shooter has injuries that are definitely survivable with treatment at the better hospital.

elements.name: question8
elements.title: “That poor victim would have no chance at all in the local civilian hospital, but the surgeon at the US military hospital might be able to save his life. You should consider transporting him.”

elements.name: question9
elements.title:
“You did your best for this guy, but his prognosis looks really bad. In his condition, he is very unlikely to even survive being transported.”

Before the medical transport arrives, the victim’s condition deteriorated quickly. Now your medical assessment is that they are very unlikely to survive even if transported. The shooter’s condition is stable, and you believe they are likely to survive if transported.

elements.name: Urban 3
elements.title: Which patient would you transport?
choices: Patient 1, the shooter
Patient 2, the victim

elements.name: Ubran Follow Up
elements.title: When you consider the decisions you made in the scenario, which factor was most important?
choices: I considered the likely medical impact.
I considered the likely medical impact and also the intent to cause harm.
I considered the likely medical impact and also the degree of responsibility for the situation.
I considered the intent to cause harm and the degree of responsibility for the situation.

elements.name: question12
elements.title: ADEPT Desert
elements.html:
ADEPT Desert


You are the medic on a helicopter en route to a remote location. It was reported that a US soldier and a local (host nation) soldier are both seriously injured. According to the report, the US soldier started a fight with another US soldier, and the local soldier tried to de-escalate. They were both seriously injured because in the struggle, they fell against a wall of a damaged building, and the wall collapsed on them.

The helicopter has one slot for a serious injury. The hospital you will take the patient to is a military facility that serves both US and indigenous forces. The patient who isn’t transported by helicopter will have to go by slower ground vehicle which could potentially aggravate their injury and risk adverse medical consequences.

elements.name: Desert 1
elements.title: Which patient would you want to evacuate?
choices: The US soldier
The local soldier

elements.name: question19
elements.title:
“It’s been a busy day down here. The injured local soldier just saved the whole group this morning by noticing an ambush setup.”

It was later in the day that the US soldier started a fight with another US soldier, and the local soldier tried to de-escalate.

elements.name: question20
elements.title:
“It’s been a busy day down here. The injured US soldier just saved the whole group this morning by noticing an ambush setup.”

It was later in the day that the US soldier started a fight with another US soldier, and the local soldier tried to de-escalate.

elements.name: Desert 2
elements.title: Which patient would you want to evacuate?
choices: The US soldier
The local soldier

elements.name: question14
elements.html: After you assess both patients, you determine that their injuries are similar. Both have injuries that are stable, but could be aggravated by a slow and bumpy evacuation by truck, so both would benefit from going by helicopter.

elements.name: question15
elements.title: “The US soldier was out of control, if the local soldier hadn’t stopped him, he would have seriously injured his own unit leader.”

elements.name: question16
elements.title: “Sometimes I’m not even sure who our enemies and allies are around here. For example, that injured local soldier. Just a few months ago, he was fighting for the insurgency against us.”

elements.name: Desert 3
elements.title: Which patient do you evacuate in the helicopter?
choices: The US soldier
The local soldier

elements.name: Desert Follow Up
elements.title: When you consider the decisions you made in that scenario, which factor was most important?
choices: I considered the intent to cause harm and the degree of responsibility for the situation.
I considered the intent to cause harm, the degree of responsibility for the situation, and helpful things each patient had done.
I considered the intent to cause harm, the degree of responsibility for the situation, the helpful things each patient had done, and the fact that the patients were from different groups
I mostly considered the fact that the patients were from different groups.

elements.name: question2
elements.html:
ADEPT Submarine


You are an IDC (the only medical provider) on a submarine, and you respond to a bad electrical accident. The Electrician Chief required one of the Electrician’s mates to work during their sleep cycle (coming off duty) to repair an electrical issue with the treadmill. A sailor who had been bugging the chief about getting it fixed for his own use was hanging around in his exercise clothes, waiting for it to be done. During the repair, there was a small electrical fire and both sailors (electrician’s mate and bystander) were seriously injured. They are reported to have similar injuries.

Crew mates are bringing the patients to you in the wardroom. The corridor is tight and they can only bring one at a time.

elements.name: Submarine 1
elements.title: Who do you want to bring in first?
choices: The Electrician’s mate
The other sailor

elements.name: question10
elements.html:
You decide to walk to the patients instead. A crewmate tells you:

“It looks like the electrician’s mate did not secure power, the most basic and important safety step, before initiating the repair! The accident was due to his serious negligence. There’s no reason it had to happen and now two people are hurt. I’m sure this will be a serious black mark on his record.”

Assessing the patients, you find that the Electrician’s mate and the other sailor are equally injured. They both need immediate treatment and are likely to survive if treated.

elements.name: Submarine 2
elements.title: Who do you treat first?
choices: The Electrician’s mate
The other sailor

elements.name: question17
elements.html:
Before you start treating either sailor, you find out that the two of them were horsing around and throwing dumbbells. When a dumbell hit the treadmill, there was a loud crack and both sailors were thrown back.

You also find out that a new patient has been discovered. They seem to have experienced a jolt from an electrical surge caused by the accident. They are in another part of the submarine. You can either stay here and treat the two sailors who caused the accident or you can go treat the new patient in another part of the submarine. All three patients need immediate treatment and are likely to survive if treated. You probably do not have time to treat all 3 patients. If you stay and treated these two sailors, you could not reach the other patient in time. If you went to treat the new patient first, you could not get back here in time to treat these two sailors.

elements.name: Submarine 3
elements.title: Who do you treat?
choices: The two sailors here
The new patient

elements.name: Submarine Follow Up
elements.title: Which factor was most important in the decisions you made in that scenario?
choices: I considered the intent to cause harm and the degree of responsibility for the situation.
I considered the intent to cause harm, the degree of responsibility for the situation, and the potential to save the most lives.
I mostly considered the potential to save the most lives.

elements.name: question6
elements.html:
ADEPT Jungle


You are a medic on a security patrol. You encounter a serious accident potentially from an IED explosion. You were told that a civilian found what looked like it might be an IED, reported it to authorities, and then against our advice, went back and apparently triggered accidental detonation while taking a closer look. There are two civilian patients, one closer to what looks like the IED materials and one further away on a path. The patient who is closer to the IED materials seems to be more seriously injured.

elements.name: Jungle 1
elements.title: Who do you treat first?
choices: The patient closer to the IED
The patient further from the IED

elements.name: question18
elements.html: As you get closer, a bystander says:

elements.name: question21
elements.title: “That man just wouldn’t leave it alone, even though he was told it could explode. He was really stupid and kept poking at it until it exploded, even though a US soldier was yelling at him to back off. Don’t you think you should help the other patient who was just in the wrong place at the wrong time?”

elements.name: question22
elements.title:
“Don’t you think the other man has a much more urgent injury compared to the man you are treating? Shouldn’t you take care of the other man first?”

You see that the patient closer to the IED is now showing more visible signs of distress. He seems to have an immediate need for treatment.

elements.name: Jungle 2
elements.title: Who do you treat first
choices: The patient closer to the IED
The patient further from the IED

elements.name: question23
elements.html:
You get radio information. “The explosion was not an accident. The man closest to it made the report to try and lure US soldiers to the site. The bomb wasn’t supposed to go off until later.”

The medical situation of the two patients has not changed.

elements.name: question24
elements.title: The patient closer to the IED is more seriously injured.

elements.name: question25
elements.title: The patient closer to the IED is more seriously injured and has an immediate need for treatment.

elements.name: Jungle 3
elements.title: You are informed there is one helicopter transport slot. Who do you transport?
choices: The patient closer to the IED
The patient further from the IED

elements.name: Jungle Follow Up
elements.title: Which factor was most important in the decisions you made in that scenario?
choices: I primarily considered the likely medical impact and tried to save the most lives.
I considered the likely medical impact and also the intent to cause harm.
I considered the likely medical impact and also the degree of responsibility for the situation.
I considered the intent to cause harm and the degree of responsibility for the situation.
